header.title: Magic, Witchcraft, and Ghosts in the Greek and Roman Worlds: A Source Book

central_thesis: This book aims to provide a comprehensive selection of translated primary sources on magic and ghosts in Graeco-Roman antiquity, emphasizing the centrality of ghosts to ancient magic and incorporating new scholarship, while making the material accessible for undergraduates and interested amateurs.

structure_content.summary: Outlines the book's aim, methodology, and the author's argument for the centrality of ghosts in ancient magic, differentiating it from existing sourcebooks.

Explores various male sorcerer types in archaic and classical Greece, including shamans (e.g., Pythagoras, Aristeas), mages, beggar-priests, evocators, and ventriloquists, highlighting their abilities such as soul-manipulation, divination, and healing.
Discusses the Greek and Roman projection of magic onto foreign peoples, primarily Persian mages, Babylonian Chaldaeans, and Egyptian priests, attributing to them diverse magical wisdom and practices.

Examines prominent male sorcerers from the first and second centuries A.D. like Apollonius of Tyana, Alexander of Abonouteichos, and Simon Magus, comparing their miraculous feats and perceived magical abilities, often framed in a neo-Pythagorean context.

Focuses on the two major mythical Greek witches, Medea and Circe, detailing their powerful drug-based magic, control over elements, reanimation, and transformations, as depicted in ancient literature.

Surveys other witch figures and witch-like women in Greek literature, including the Deianeira tradition, minor witches, and Simaetha, emphasizing their use of love potions and other magical practices.
Explores Latin literary representations of witches, such as Canidia, Erictho, and Meroe, highlighting their bloodthirsty rituals, necromancy, love magic, and the collection of cadaverous materials.

Categorizes restless dead (untimely, violent, unmarried, unburied) and their exploitation in magic, including ghost-laying, exorcism, exploitation of boys' souls, and werewolves, with narratives of haunted houses.
Details the practice of divination from the dead, including evocation (at oracles or tombs) and reanimation of corpses, and explores other varieties of magical divination.
Analyzes binding curses (katadesmoi/defixiones) found on tablets, covering legal, competition, trade, erotic, and justice-seeking curses, and discusses the role of the evil eye.
Focuses on spells of separation and attraction, including the drawing down of the moon, iunx/rhombos, hippomanes, and techniques for contraception or abortion, often from Greek magical papyri.
Examines kolossoi (voodoo dolls) and similar magical images, their relation to curse tablets, and their use in erotic magic and ghost-laying.
Discusses various types of amulets (periamma/periapton) for protection, healing, exorcism, erotic attraction, and luck, and their physical forms and inscriptions.

Covers legislation against magic in Greek and Roman cultures, forensic speeches on magical subjects (Apuleius's Apology, Libanius's Against the Lying Mage), and the legal context of magical practices.

key_concepts.definition: A male sorcerer in Greek antiquity, characterized by soul manipulation (detaching/sending on voyages/suspending life/reincarnating/bilocating), divination, control of elements, and association with Hyperborean Apollo. Flourished in archaic period, linked to Pythagorean and Orphic traditions.
A largely hostile term for nebulous male magical professionals, concerned with curing illness, manufacturing curse tablets, well-being of the soul, purifications, incantations, and binding spells.
A term for professional wise men, often associated with Persian, Babylonian, or Egyptian origins in Graeco-Roman tradition, possessing expertise in religious matters, astronomy, astrology, and magic.
Individuals who call up the souls of the dead for various purposes, including divination, often employing specific rituals involving pits, sacrifices, blood, and prayers to underworld powers.
Persons whose stomachs are inhabited by a prophetic demon or ghost that speaks through them, using the host as a mouthpiece.
Ghosts of those who died before their time, often children or babies, believed to be restless and to haunt the living.
Ghosts of those who died by violence, including battle-dead and executed criminals, considered particularly bitter and powerful.
Ghosts of those denied due burial, believed to be unable to achieve rest and to wander restlessly until proper funeral rites are performed.

Curse tablets, typically inscribed on lead, rolled, and nailed, deposited in graves or bodies of water to bind or restrain victims, often enacted by ghosts or underworld powers for legal, competitive, trade, or erotic purposes.
A general term for magical substances or preparations, often herbs, used by witches and sorcerers for various effects, including healing, transformation, love, and poisoning.

Erotic-magical implements; the iunx is a whistling wheel, often metal, spun with a thread, named after the wryneck bird, used in mating dances; rhombos is a bull-roarer or rhomboid block of wood/metal spun in the air. Both used to compel love.

A love-potion ingredient, applied to various substances: an herb, a growth on newborn foal's forehead, a mare's discharge, or stallion's semen, believed to induce 'horse-madness' or strong sexual desire.
Demonic names or meaningless polysyllables, often capitalized in modern translations, believed to possess divine power and used in incantations and curses, often rooted in Egyptian or Hebrew names.
A form of divination involving observation of flashes or images in the surface of a liquid in a bowl or dish, often performed by boys in a hypnotic state, and sometimes for necromantic purposes.
A form of divination involving observation of flashes or images in the flickering of a lamp, or its shadowing, often performed in conjunction with lecanomancy.
Protective or empowering magical objects, often simple tied threads or inscribed lamellae/gemstones worn on the body, used for various purposes including healing, exorcism, and erotic attraction.
Figurines, often made of wax or clay, used in binding magic to represent victims, with manipulations on the doll (binding, piercing) intended to affect the individual, also used in ghost-laying.

practical_system.description: The book compiles diverse ancient Graeco-Roman magical systems and philosophies, primarily focusing on practices described in literary and documentary texts from approximately 776 B.C. to 476 A.D. These systems are characterized by various practitioner types (shamans, mages, witches), methods of manipulating spiritual and material realms, and the exploitation of specific entities like ghosts and demons. The book itself is a sourcebook, not a practical manual; the following describes the ancient systems it documents.
tools: Curse Tablets (Lead, wax, papyrus): Inscribed with binding spells, often rolled, folded, or pierced with nails.
Voodoo Dolls (Kolossoi): Figurines of wax, clay, lead, or wool, often bound, mutilated, or pierced with pins, used in sympathetic magic for attraction, separation, or ghost-laying.
Amulets (Lamellae, gemstones, threads): Worn on the body, inscribed with divine names, symbols, or spells for protection or specific magical effects.
Herbs and Drugs (Pharmaka): Various plants, animal parts, and mixed concoctions used in potions, lotions, or fumigations for healing, transformations, love magic, or inducing madness/sterility.
Magic Wheels (Iunx/Rhombos): Whistling wheels or bull-roarers, typically made of metal, spun with threads to compel erotic desire.
Lamps and Bowls: Used in lychnomancy and lecanomancy for scrying and divination.
Swords/Daggers: Used in necromantic rituals for sacrifices and to manage restless ghosts, which are feared to be repelled by bronze/iron.
Sacred Names/Voces Magicae: Invocations of powerful divine or demonic names, often in foreign languages, used in spells, exorcisms, and curses.
rituals: Necromancy: Evocation of the dead (ghosts or reanimated corpses) for divination or information, often involving pits, blood sacrifices (black animals), libations (honey-milk, wine, water), and prayers to underworld deities (Hades, Persephone, Hecate).

Binding Curses (Katadesmoi/Defixiones): Inscribing names and intentions on lead tablets, often with twisted writing or symbols, nailing them, and depositing them in graves, wells, or chthonic sanctuaries to bind or confuse rivals (legal, athletic, trade) or compel erotic desire.

Erotic Magic: Spells of attraction (e.g., drawing down the moon, using iunx/rhombos, hippomanes, love potions, voodoo dolls) and separation (curses to make a beloved forget a rival), often involving ritual acts, specific ingredients, and invocations of deities like Aphrodite or Hecate.

Exorcism and Ghost-Laying: Rituals to expel possessing demons or restless ghosts from individuals or haunted houses, often involving incantations, specific herbs, physical tokens, and appeals to powerful names (e.g., Solomon, Jesus).

Divination: Practices like lecanomancy (bowl-divination), lychnomancy (lamp-divination), and catoptromancy (mirror-divination), often involving boys as seers, observing flashes or images in liquids/flames/mirrors to gain foreknowledge.

Amuletic Protection: Crafting and wearing inscribed lamellae, gemstones, or knotted threads for protection against spells, diseases (e.g., epilepsy, hysteria), the evil eye, or to bestow favor and luck.

relevant_quotes.text: The aim of this book is to provide a selection of sources in translation for magic and ghosts in Graeco-Roman antiquity that does the following: ... • Selects and presents sources with an eye to important developments in the new scholarship on these subjects.

If there is one overriding argument implicit in the book, it is, as the title itself indicates, the contention of the centrality of ghosts to ancient magic: they were not its only motor, but it is fair to say that they were its chief one.

Gives clearly and systematically for all passages their chief significance, their authorship (or provenance), their citation, their date of composition, and their original language. • Provides all sources in original translations. Particular care has been taken in the selection of text-editions for the magical documents.

critical_analysis.relevance: The book addresses the 'explosion in interest in ancient magic and the related field of ghosts among scholars of classical antiquity,' offering a single-volume sourcebook to meet the needs of undergraduate courses and scholars, providing accessible translations of challenging source material, especially curse tablets and amulets.
critical_analysis.target_audience: Undergraduates and interested amateurs, including those with an interest in ancient social history or the occult, who seek readily accessible material to make up their own minds on the definition and practice of magic and ghosts.
